awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a CryoProbe-Enabled NMR Spectrometer for Enhanced Efficiency and Sensitivity in Chemical and Biological Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is jointly supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Boston College is acquiring a 500 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer equipped with liquid nitrogen cooled probe to support the research of Professor Thusitha Jayasundera and colleagues James Morken, Jianmin Gao, Jeffery Byers and Jia Niu. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as permitting study of chemically and biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. The probe uses nitrogen-cooled radiofrequency coils that deliver a much greater sensitivity enhancement over room temperature. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution as well as collaborators from neighboring colleges including primarily undergraduate institutions. In addition, the instrument is part of activities involving the NSF funded Boston College Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program and the Paper to Plastics (P2P) summer program, as well as other outreach initiatives, such as the Women in Science and Technology (WST) program. These programs are largely composed of women, first generation students, and/or minorities that are under-represented in STEM disciplines.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the development of non-noble metal-based catalysts and the characterization of synthesized molecules to interrogate biomolecules that cannot be targeted pharmacologically, commonly referred as "undruggable". The instrumentation is also used for developing new synthetic methods for applications in organic chemistry and for identifying macromolecules prepared with tailor-made structures and sequences. In addition, it allows the characterization of species used in metalloradical catalysis and for understanding molecular interactions in microbiome communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: MRI: Acquisition of a CryoProbe-Enabled NMR Spectrometer for Enhanced Efficiency and Sensitivity in Chemical and Biological Research

Federal Award ID: CHE-2117246

Report Submission Period: 09/01/2023 to 08/31/2024

Director/PI: Thusitha Jayasundera, Ph.D.

Co-PI: Jeffrey Byers, D.Phil.

Co-PI: Jianmin Gao, Ph.D.

Co-PI: James Morken, Ph.D.

Co-PI: Jia Niu, Ph.D.

 

Funds from this award were used to purchase a CryoProbe-Enabled Bruker NEO NMR spectrometer for the Magnetic Resonance Center (MRC) at Boston College (BC), with the installation completed by April 2022. Despite a few initial hardware failures (the probe had to be sent out for repair after just four weeks, then a quenched shim coil had to be reenergized the next year) that were covered by the initial warranty and service contract, the system has been working very reliably. The 100-150 strong graduate and undergraduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and principal investigators that utilize the facility for numerous research and outreach projects have successfully used this instrument to generate valuable data to propel their work and enhance the scope of the numerous research projects that utilize the MRC. In addition, the system has been utilized by students from neighboring institutions, and also played a major role in several undergraduate classes. These positive outcomes over the last two years are detailed below.

Outcomes: Intellectual Merit

The most significant positive outcome that reinforces the scope of the intellectual merit of this project (as of June 2024) are the 38 peer-reviewed journal articles that have been published by the research groups at BC that utilized data acquired on this instrument. The areas of expertise span a wide-ranging list of sub specialties in chemistry, such as synthetic organic (small molecules, drugs), biological (bio polymers), and physical (battery research) branches. Our researchers have been able to fully exploit the high sensitivity (CryoProbe), and new capabilities (observing esoteric nuclei, easily accessible low temperature work, previously unavailable novel experimental setups) afforded by this spectrometer, culminating in the impressive list of publications mentioned above. Additionally, a high percentage of female and minority students and postdocs that train on this system has been central to distributing the scholarly accomplishments among various underrepresented groups.

Outcomes: Broader Impacts

This new instrument has had several broader impacts in addition to the intellectual merit discussed above. The most significant impact has been the addition of valuable capacity to the MRC, which was in dire need of a new NMR spectrometer following two older models (one ~30 years old) reaching the end of life and being obsolete at the time. The extra capacity has allowed this spectrometer to be a great resource to several students from the nearby University of Massachusetts at Boston, who needed to acquire NMR data when their MR-400 system was out of commission for a lengthy duration. The use of the instrument and staff guidance was provided free-of-charge, staying true to the Jesuit values at BC. The increased capacity was also a major factor in our ability to use this instrument for four courses (one with a brand new, semester-long lab modules related to NMR applications in biology) during the year, with students receiving hands-on experience on spectrometer use. One final outcome thanks to the added capacity has been the increase in time dedicated to outreach programs that train, for example, undergraduate students who are part of the first-generation or underrepresented minority group programs at BC. Once again, the members of each small cohort receive hands-on training in operating the instrument, with short lectures to introduce the theory and guide them through the data acquisition and interpretation processes. 

Summary

The federal award CHE-2117246 was used to purchase a CryoProbe-Enabled Bruker NEO NMR spectrometer for the MRC at BC. The project was a success, resulting in positive outcomes related to both, intellectual merit and broader impacts, as described above. The spectrometer continues to be a valuable resource to researchers at BC as well as other universities in close proximity, while playing a central role in the teaching and outreach activities centers on the MRC as well.
